definitions: view or represent a person or group according to an oversimplified fixed idea or image
examples: People often stereotype teenagers as being irresponsible and rebellious
Don't stereotype all lawyers as greedy money-seekers

definitions: cook food slowly by simmering in liquid in a closed dish or pan
be in a state of anxiety or agitation about something
examples: She likes to stew vegetables with herbs for dinner
The beef needs to stew for at least two hours
He continued to stew about his mistake all weekend
Don't stew over things you cannot change or control

definitions: prevent or constrain an activity or suppress the development or expression of something
make someone unable to breathe properly or suffocate
examples: The strict rules stifle creativity in the classroom environment
She tried to stifle a yawn during the boring presentation
The smoke from the fire began to stifle the trapped workers
The heavy blanket seemed to stifle him in his sleep

definitions: encourage interest or activity in a person or thing to develop or increase
raise levels of physiological or nervous activity in the body or any biological system
examples: The teacher uses games to stimulate student interest in learning
Good questions stimulate thoughtful discussion in the classroom meetings
Coffee stimulates the nervous system and increases alertness levels
Exercise stimulates blood flow throughout the entire body system

definitions: wound or pierce with a sharp-pointed venomous organ or object
feel or cause to feel a sharp tingling or burning pain or sensation
hurt someone emotionally or affect painfully
examples: The bee will sting if you disturb its nest
Be careful not to let the jellyfish sting you
The cold wind made her cheeks sting painfully outside
The antiseptic will sting when applied to the wound
His harsh criticism really stung her deeply inside
The rejection letter from the university stung his pride

definitions: have a strong unpleasant smell that is offensive to the senses
be very bad or unpleasant in quality or character
examples: The garbage began to stink in the summer heat
His old gym shoes really stink after practice sessions
This whole situation stinks of corruption and dishonesty everywhere
The movie was terrible and the acting really stinks

definitions: supply an ungenerous or inadequate amount of something by being economical to excess
examples: Don't stint on quality when buying safety equipment items
She never stints on ingredients when cooking for her family

definitions: demand or specify a requirement typically as part of a bargain or agreement
examples: The contract stipulates payment within thirty days of delivery
The rules stipulate that all players must wear protective gear

definitions: make join or mend something by sewing with needle and thread
join or unite things together especially with thread or similar material
examples: She learned to stitch buttons on shirts by hand
The tailor will stitch the hem of your new pants
The doctor needed to stitch the deep cut carefully
Can you stitch these fabric pieces together for the quilt

definitions: accumulate a large stock of goods or materials for future use
examples: Many people stockpile food before a major storm arrives
The country began to stockpile weapons during the tense period

definitions: add coal or other solid fuel to a fire furnace or boiler
encourage or incite an emotion or tendency to increase
examples: He went outside to stoke the campfire with more wood
Someone needs to stoke the furnace on cold winter nights
His comments only served to stoke anger among the protesters
The media coverage continues to stoke fears about the economy

definitions: tread heavily and noisily typically in order to show anger
examples: The angry child began to stomp around the room loudly
Don't stomp on the stairs when people are sleeping below

definitions: delay or block a request process or person by refusing to answer questions or by giving evasive replies
examples: The witness tried to stonewall the investigation with vague answers
The company continues to stonewall reporters asking about the scandal

definitions: act as a subordinate or compliant assistant especially to a comedian or criminal
examples: He refused to stooge for the corrupt politician any longer
The comedian needs someone to stooge for him during performances

definitions: bend one's head or body forward and downward from upright position
lower oneself morally or socially by doing something beneath one's dignity
examples: She had to stoop to get through the low doorway
He stooped to pick up the coin from the sidewalk
I won't stoop to their level by spreading harmful gossip
She would never stoop to cheating on an important exam

definitions: close or seal something with a stopper cork or similar device
examples: Remember to stopper the bottle after pouring the wine
She carefully stoppered all the test tubes in the laboratory

definitions: pack or store an object carefully and neatly in a particular place
examples: Please stow your luggage in the overhead compartment carefully
The sailors stow equipment below deck before the storm arrives

definitions: sit or stand with one leg on either side of something
place oneself on both sides of something or favor both sides of an issue
examples: The cowboy knows how to straddle a horse properly
She had to straddle the motorcycle to start the engine
The town straddles the border between two different countries
Politicians often straddle controversial issues to avoid losing voters

definitions: make or become straight from curved bent or twisted shape
make tidy or put things in proper order
examples: Use a flat iron to straighten your hair before work
The orthodontist will straighten her teeth over two years
Let me straighten the room before our guests arrive tonight
He needs to straighten out his finances before buying property

definitions: leave someone without the means to move from somewhere typically in isolation
examples: The storm stranded travelers at the airport for two days
Don't let the boat engine fail and strand us offshore

definitions: kill by squeezing the throat to prevent breathing
suppress or hinder the development or activity of something
examples: The victim was strangled with a rope around the neck
The python can strangle its prey before eating it whole
High taxes strangle small business growth in the community
Overregulation will strangle innovation in the technology sector completely

definitions: fasten or secure in a specified place or position with a strap or straps
examples: Remember to strap the baby into the car seat securely
The workers strap cargo to the truck before long trips

definitions: move away aimlessly from a group or from the right course or place
move without a specific purpose or by mistake especially from a set area
examples: Don't let the children stray too far from the campsite
His thoughts began to stray during the long boring lecture
The lost dog would stray through neighborhoods looking for food
Be careful not to stray from the marked hiking trail

definitions: design or provide with a form that presents very little resistance to a flow of air or water increasing speed and ease of movement
make an organization or system more efficient and effective by employing faster or simpler working methods
examples: Engineers streamline car designs to improve fuel efficiency ratings
The company streamlined its production process to reduce costs significantly

definitions: walk with long decisive steps in a specified direction
examples: She would stride confidently into the boardroom every morning
The tall man could stride across the field very quickly

definitions: mark with stripes or lines of contrasting color or texture
examples: The painter will stripe the parking lot spaces this weekend
They decided to stripe the walls with bold colorful patterns

definitions: walk in a leisurely way without hurrying as for pleasure
examples: The couple likes to stroll through the park after dinner
Let's stroll along the beach and enjoy the sunset together

definitions: play a stringed instrument by sweeping the thumb or fingers across strings
examples: She learned to strum basic chords on her new guitar
He would strum his ukulele while sitting on the porch

definitions: walk with a stiff proud gait typically with chest thrust out trying to impress others
examples: The rooster would strut around the farmyard every morning proudly
He began to strut after winning the championship game yesterday

definitions: accidentally strike one's toe or foot against something
examples: Be careful not to stub your toe on the furniture
She stubbed her foot on a rock while walking barefoot

definitions: coat or decorate with fine plaster used for coating wall surfaces or molding into architectural decorations
examples: They plan to stucco the exterior walls of the house
The contractor will stucco the ceiling with decorative patterns tomorrow

definitions: decorate or augment something with many studs or similar small objects
examples: She wants to stud her leather jacket with silver pieces
The designer will stud the handbag with colorful rhinestones carefully

definitions: baffle or perplex someone completely with a difficult question or problem
examples: The final question really stumped all the quiz contestants completely
This math problem has stumped even the brightest students today

definitions: shock or astonish someone so much they are temporarily unable to react
knock unconscious or into a dazed or semiconscious state
examples: The surprising news seemed to stun everyone in the room
Her incredible performance on stage managed to stun the audience
The blow to his head was enough to stun him
The electric shock can stun fish for easy capture underwater

definitions: prevent from growing or developing properly by adverse conditions or lack of resources
examples: Poor nutrition can stunt a child's physical and mental development
Lack of sunlight will stunt the plant's growth this season

definitions: talk with continued involuntary repetition of sounds especially initial consonants
examples: He tends to stutter when he feels nervous or anxious
The child began to stutter after the traumatic experience happened

definitions: act as a substitute for someone especially in a sports team or at work
examples: Can you sub for me at work next Friday afternoon
The coach asked him to sub for the injured player

definitions: divide something that has already been divided or that is a unit
examples: The developer plans to subdivide the land into smaller lots
We need to subdivide this large task into manageable sections

definitions: overcome quieten or bring under control a feeling or person
make someone or something less intense loud or strong
examples: The police managed to subdue the violent suspect without injury
She tried to subdue her anger before speaking to him
The medication helps subdue the pain from her chronic condition
Soft lighting can subdue the harsh atmosphere of the room

definitions: bring under domination or control especially by conquest making someone or something subordinate to another
examples: The empire sought to subjugate all neighboring territories by force
Throughout history powerful nations have tried to subjugate weaker ones

definitions: lease all or part of a property to another person while still holding the lease oneself
examples: She decided to sublet her apartment during her overseas assignment
The company policy doesn't allow tenants to sublet their offices

definitions: cause to be under water or other liquid completely
completely cover or obscure something
examples: The submarine can submerge to great depths below the surface
Don't submerge the electronic device in water or liquid
The flood waters will submerge the entire valley by tomorrow
Try not to submerge yourself completely in work responsibilities

definitions: treat or regard as of lesser importance than something else making it secondary
examples: You should subordinate personal interests to the team's success
The manager tends to subordinate new ideas to established procedures

definitions: summon someone with a writ ordering them to attend a court
examples: The court will subpoena witnesses to testify at the trial
They plan to subpoena company records for the investigation process

definitions: arrange to receive something regularly typically a publication by paying in advance
express or feel agreement with an idea or proposal
examples: Many people subscribe to streaming services for entertainment content
I subscribe to several magazines about cooking and home design
I don't subscribe to the theory that money brings happiness
She doesn't subscribe to traditional views about women's roles today

definitions: become less intense violent or severe over a period of time
sink to a lower or normal level
examples: The storm will subside by tomorrow morning according to forecasts
Wait for the pain to subside before attempting to walk
The flood waters began to subside after three days
The swelling in her ankle should subside with proper rest

definitions: support an organization or activity financially typically by government or public body
examples: The government will subsidise renewable energy projects this year
Many countries subsidise their agricultural sectors to support farmers

definitions: support an organization or activity financially typically by government or public body
examples: The state plans to subsidize public transportation for all residents
Some companies subsidize employee health insurance costs each month

definitions: maintain or support oneself especially at a minimal level with basic necessities
examples: Many families subsist on very low incomes in developing countries
The refugees had to subsist on limited food rations daily

definitions: provide evidence to support or prove the truth of a claim statement or finding
examples: The lawyer needs to substantiate her claims with solid evidence
Can you substantiate these accusations with any documented proof available
